arm_group.description: CO2 laser treatment of mild to severe acne scars at 1 month interval
CO2 laser treatment of mild to severe acne scars at 3 month intervals

brief_summary.textblock:
To compare efficacy and adverse effects of fractional CO2 laser of acne scars treatment with
      1 versus 3 months intervals

clinical_study.brief_title: Treatment of Atrophic Acne Scars With a Fractional CO2 Laser at 1 Versus 3 Months Intervals

detailed_description.textblock:
Change in scar texture evaluated by blinded evalutaions. Appearance of erythema, oedema,
      pigmentation, infection after treatment

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Have Fitzpatrick skin type I-III. (•Are male or female.

          -  Are between 18 and 60 years of age.

          -  Mild to severe acne scarring.

          -  Are able to read, understand, and sign the Informed Consent.

          -  Are willing and able to comply with all follow-up requirements  -

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Have had active localized or systemic infections within 6 months of enrollment

          -  Have compromised ability for wound healing, such as: malnutrition, oral steroid use,
             history of collagen vascular disease (e.g. lupus, scleroderma, history of keloid
             formation (raised and thickened scars), atrophic dermatitis (extreme skin irritation
             or itchiness) or immunologic abnormalities such as vitiligo (white patches of skin
             due to loss of pigment)

          -  Have been treated with lasers, chemical procedures, or other cosmetic procedures on
             the area to be treated within 6 months of enrollment

          -  Pregnancy

intervention.description: Fractionel CO2 laser: 1 versus 3 months intervals

clinical_study.official_title: Treatment of Atrophic Acne Scars With a Fractional CO2 Laser at 1 Versus 3 Months Intervals. A Randomized Controlled Trial With Blinded Response Evaluations

oversight_info.authority: Denmark: The Regional Committee on Biomedical Research Ethics

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Appearance of erythema, oedema, pigmentation, infection

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment
